ARTICLE.TITLE: Government is 'working on a plan' to stop local authorities going bankrupt
ARTICLE.TEXT:

The Government is "working on a plan" to stop local councils going bankrupt, Downing Street says.

It follows warnings that councils are set to run out of money as a result of the coronavirus crisis, with Birmingham City Council facing the biggest financial shortfall in the country.

An investigation by the BBC's shared data unit found Birmingham, the nation's largest local authority, is facing a funding gap of £212 million - despite already receiving an emergency grant of more than £70 million from the Government.

Like other councils, Birmingham has been hit by an increase in costs, including the cost of providing food to some families, at the same time as its income has fallen.

Some authorities, such as Leeds and Barnet, have said they may have to issue a section 114 notice, which effectively means declaring themselves bankrupt.

Prime Minister Boris Johnson's spokesman said: "We are working on a plan to ensure councils have financial sustainability for the year ahead and we will continue to work closely with them to understand the costs that they are facing.

"We are working on the plan now, and we'll set out more details in due course."

He said "unprecedented" support had already been provided to councils, including £3.2bn of additional funding, bringing forward payments of social care grants of £850m and allowing councils to defer £2.6bn in business rate payments.

But in a letter to the Prime Minister back in April, city council leader Ian Ward said; "Whilst we are grateful for the financial support offered, unfortunately, it is in no way adequateto meet the ongoing call on the Council’s resources, arising out of Covid-19, in a city of overone million people."

He warned: "Without sufficient funding from central Government, the ability of the City Council to recover financially ... will be compromised, and with it our ability to deliver vital public services in the medium term - at a time when our communities need us the most."

Sir Richard Leese, Labour leader of Manchester City Council, said his administration was looking at a financial loss of £166 million, with a shortfall of £31 million this year and £162 million in the next – a quarter of its net budget.

Speaking to BBC Radio 4’s Today programme, Sir Richard said warnings to the Government that the council might need to use a Section 114 order – effectively declaring bankruptcy – was a warning that it would not be able to afford to look after the most vulnerable in society if more cash was not forthcoming.

He said: “This is more than a plea for help. This is saying there are things the law says we have to do that we simply will not be able to do unless we get more funding.

“And a very substantial amount of funding.”
